div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gilbratar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Moday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at he very convienient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returnin within 12 months.
In addition to the above weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marsielles
TO THE EAST

The mail steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightlyy, and another for Japan. Passnegers embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for return from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find a special though carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Koweit
div.p: The causes that have led Sheikh Mubarak ibn Sabah to hoist the Ottoman fitg over his capital are obscure at present, but we are inclined to think that the Porte, by resorting to something like a commercial boycott, has injured the trade of the port to suoh an extent that its inhabitants have compelled their rnler to accept a Turkish protectorate. The port lies at the junction of two trade roates, the land route from Basra and Mesohed Ali and the oarav&n road from the Neji to the Persian Qalf. The first of these lines is entirely under Ottoman oontro1, and if the news that the Nejd has been oocnpied, in part at least, by troops coming from Bagdad and Basra, is accurate, it will be readily under­stood that its trade with Kowe t oan be checked or diverted by an energetic com­mandant. For some time past the Anglo- Indian Government exeroised a veiled pro­tectorate over Eoweit. Its ehief receive i a subvention, a British resident watched the politics of the Nejd and the Eaphrates valley, and British steamers caUed regularly at the excellent harbonr that was destined to be the terminus of the Bagdad railway. Mnbarak Ibn Sabah attacked and defeated Ibn Rashid of Hail last winter, and the rnmonra of the Damascus bazaars asoribed his success to the presence of officers of the Indian Army! An attempt on the part 6f the Tarks to counter by meins of a military demonstration against Koweit drew the British East Indian Sqnadron to the Persian Golf and the protests of the Ottoman Government passed by Lord Laus- downe unheeded.

What, then, is the oause of this volteface on the part of Mubirak t His the new Govern­ment decided to abandon the polioy of safe­guarding the independence of I£oweit, in the hope of avoiding friotiqn with the Oftoo^n and, indireotly, the German Empire, whose publicists have long demanded the Establish­ment of a ooaling depot at t^e future terrainnq of life grand tranff line frpm Hamburg to t^e Persian Gu f I Qr has Mnbarak, exposed to constant pressure from the land side,deoided to follow the Raltan raiher than the Vioaroy and to brave a naval demonstration f A few wreks will nodonbt clear up the mystery bat if tli3 nt Ws of Sheikh Mubarak's defec ion is trae, British diplomacy in the Persian Galf seems to have experienced a distinot reverse. Bat by whose hand is this reverse mfUoted—by the supple fingers of the Sublime Porte eyer ready, like AutQlyoaa, to snap up suoh unoonsidered trifles as Dthala, Koweit, Taba, and Solum, or by the redoubtable mailed fist which ought the emblem of the German Empire

In spite of the disturbed condition of Russia, the Bible Sooiety's agent in St. Petersburg reports a circulation of over half-a-stillion copies of the Scriptures during 1905. This is exclusive of a large circulation in Siberia, of which complete statistios are not yet to hand. So f*r, the Bible Sooiety's workers and depots in the.Rnssian Empire have in noway suffered dming the recent disturbances. The Sooiety's agent in Siberia writes from Ekaterinburg : "Our gnat need is more books. The stock has ran ont, and owing to strikes the forwarding of fresh supplies is somewhat erratic. The soldiers as they went East promised to boy, if spared, as they returned from the war. The balk of them looked upon this as a solemn vow, and are baying Bibles and Testaments freely. We have never before Bold so many in so short a period,"

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage, Ramleh.
div.p: This favourite Ramleh hotel has reopened for the summer season. A number of tonrists and residents have already pnt op at this healthy seaside resort. The hotel oan specially be reoommended to visitors joining their stea­mers at Alexandria, giving them the oppor­tunity to enjoy a pleasant stay near the sea before their departure. The hotel is only 25 minutes distance from Alexandria by eleotrio iram and oars run every 5 minutes.
Cairo and the Megaphone Dragoman.

It is quite on the cards that Cairo may next season be invaded by the sight-seeing motor char-k-banc, accompanied by a megaphone lecturer, whioh is a feature of New York. Five companies are operating there and doing a great basiness in showing country visitors the sights by night and day—"seeing New York" it is called. A oompany which is coming to London with fifteen motor-waggor ettes is pre­paring to run four distinct tours around Lon­don, including all the sights of the rich and poor quarters, the historic and fashionable dis­tricts, and Dickensland. Each car will be accompanied by a gbide with a megaphone. That guide will also be a comedian trained aocording to the New York system, to point out prominent buildings and make amusing personal comments, besides providing gossip and criticisms when indicating notable hoases or personages. The experts will all be Lon­doners. The companies' operations will be carried on in London daring the season, and in Paris, Berlin, and Monte Carlo afterwards. The operations will be extended, if Fuccessful, to Cairn, until eventually wherever the tide of fa«hioD flows the voice of the "man with the megaphone" will resound

div.head: Alexandria Municipaltiy
div.p: Presentation to Mr. Ball
Souvenir from the personnel
Mr. Ambroise A. Ralli, vice-president of the Alexandria Municipality, was this morning presented with a sonvenir on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of his taking up office.

The presentation of the sonvenir was the occasion of a spontaneous demonstration on the part of the staff of the Municipality, who assembled in the large counoil-ohamber to express their esteem and appreciation for the many benefits they had received at Mr. Ralli's hands and for the great interest he had always shown in the'r welfare and advance­ment. They hoped that for many years to oome he would continue to ocoupy the high position he has held for so long and wonld Dover cease to show the same keen disinterestedness on behalf of the welfare of the inhabitants of Egypt's commercial Capital.

The Secretary of the Alexandria Manioipa- lity, in a few eloquent word*, expressed the gratitude of the staff for the goodness of heart which Mr. Ralli had always displayed in behalf of their interests.

Mr. Ralli, who was visibly touched by the spontaneity of this demonstration, replied to this cordial manifestation and testified to the great pleasure that had been afforded him by this unexpeoted incident.

The artistic and sumptuous sonvenir was enclosed in a case of Morocco leather. It con­sisted of a oigarette-osse, match box, and card- case in solid gold, with an "art nonvean" design of most exquisite workmanship em­bossed with diamond* and sapphires.
The following inscription was engraved in the interior of the cigarette case :—
Souvenir d'estime et de reconnaissance du Per­sonnel de la Municipality d'Alexandrie A M, A, Ralli, Vic* President.
A written address was also handed to Mr. Ralli enclosed in a Morocco case bearing his initials in gold.

div.head: Arrival of the Arabic
div.p: Jerusalem, March 8.

The White Star liner Arabic, chartered by Mr. Frank Clark, and conveying 630 American tonrists, archored off Jaffa th's morning after having landed at Haifia yesterday about 70 of the number to reach Jerusalem overland through Galilee and Samaria The re3t of the passengers arrived here this afternoon by special trains. After viriting theHoly City and neighboorhood the tonrists will embark for Alexandria on the 13th instant.

div.head: The latest Water Colour Exhibition
div.p: The room at the National Hotel so lately noonpied by Mr. Lamplonph's collection of sketobes is now adorned by the work of two clever ladies, Miss Katherine McCracken and Miss Nellie Haddon, the last of whom belongs to the Royal Miniature Society and is well known by the olever animal sketches she contribotes to the "Sphere." These two ladies only arrived in Cairo last November, and the work they have achieved since then speaks well for their enterprise and industry. Miss McCrac­ken is responsible for over fifty excellent water­colour sketches taken in Cairo and its neigh­bourhood, and her studies of the busy street life with its complications of architectore and wealth of eoloor are admirable in colour and composition. More especially she is to be com mended for her piotnres entitled "In the Gamalieh," and "On the way to the Citadel." A olever sketch of Ghizeh has already been purchased by Mrs. Bollock and Coact Wels- borg has also expressed bis admiration of her work by baying another. Mr. Talbot Kelly has become the possessor of a study of the bine tiled mosqne, an extremely interesting snbjeot, and doubtless many other piotnres of local life will find ready purchasers before the week's exhibition is over.

Miss Haddon has been spending much or her time in the Zoological Gardens, where Captain Flower has given her every facility for carrying oat her appreciation of animal life. Many reproductions of her works will be even­tually produced in the "Sphere," and others have already been published in London. The very interesting collection of lion cnbs, obtain­ed from ap-coontry by Captain Flower and now on their way to stock the Indian jungles, form the subject of a pioture entitled "Lion cobs by the drzen," and the baby elephants, "The Three Graces," with their keeper, have received due recognition at her hand. The study of the "Burrowing owls and marmots" was taken from the London Z o, where these birds and animals have been placed together in an enclo­sure as like as possible to their own habitat, but the white donkey and his boy were found here in Cairo.

Miss Haddon has also on exhibition some delightfully delicate miniatures, two especially worthy of mention, "Ma b lie foeor" and "Por­trait of Mrs. Ogilvie," both of which have a very effective and decorative scheme of back­ground. The miniatore of an intelligent little errier sitting op at table before a glass of wine has for its title "Drink to me only with 1 bine eyes," and there are two piotnres of a lr cal water carrier, one a small head and the other the full figure against an excellently rendered background, which conld rift be im­proved upon, e'ther for delicacy of exprrs-ion or colouring. Mr. Talbot Kelly has also pnr- chasf d sev: rai of Mhh Haddon's works,and it is to be hope 1 that many another art lover will give these ladies the recognition they deserve.

div.head: Notes from Suakin
div.p: Railway staff reduced
workmen replaced by troops
(From our Correspondent).
Suakin, March 7.

The staff of the Sadan Government Railways has been greatly reduced lately in all depart­ments, especially in the Suakin-Atbara district, on the score of economy. Several engine- drivers, station-masters, gaards, and points­men are also being replaced by soldiers from the Railway Battalion. All porterage for load­ing and unloading goods at any station is now carried ont by soldiers instead of native work­men. About 2,f00 Arab labourers have been discharged since Jar nary.
Wells aro being bored now at stations between Tbamiam and Kassala line under the direotion of Bimbashi Newoombe, R E.
Captain Mahon, R.E., is now on survey from Omdurman to El-Obeid.
Rev. Paxton has left for Khartoum and El Kaimakam Hayes-Sadler Bey, Direotor of Sadan Customs, for Dongola, to organize the Customs there.

The Suakin annual sports, which were postponed owing to the unfortunate death by accident of an Egyptian Army officer took place on the 5th iust. The sports were a great success and the afternoon was spent in an enjoyable manner. The band and bag pipes of the 6th Battalion E.A. were in atten­dance.

div.head: Big Engineering Combine
div.p: A combination of some of the best-known English engineering firms established in Egypt is now being formed under the direotion of some London financial specialists. The com­bine will, in a few weeks' time, be launched simultaneously in London, Cairo and Alexan­dria as a limited liability oompany with a oapital of £300,000. The shares are already being dealt in on the Cairo Bourse at a pre­mium. The oapital will consist of 295,000 ordinary shares of £1 eaoh and 5,000 fally-paid deferred shares.

The combine embraces an amalgamation of fonr engineering firms at Cairo, Alexandria, and elsewhere in the Delta. The oompany also has some very valuable land options. Ths public issue will take plaoe next month. Thera is a strong London Board and a local advisory Board. The whole of the necessary workieg oapital has been firmly guaranteed in England and Egypt.

div.head: Egyptian Banking Extraordinary
div.p: COMMERCIAL BANK OF EGYPT.

There has recently been registered the Com­mercial Bank of Egypt (Limited) with a capita* consisting of 2 000 shilling shares or £100 in all. In spite of th« faot that the promoters announce that they will make no initial pablio issue—-saohan announcement by the way mean­ing nothing, or next to it—it might have been thought that the idea of inability to raise such a moderate amount of capital for a banking institution wonld never have entered into anyone's head. The articles of association provide, however, that in the event of the whole of the shares not being snbscribsd by the end of this month the company shall be dissolved. Dissolution would perhaps not be regrettable. The "Morning Post," in oom mooting on this bank, remarks, ' No donbt formality is the explanation of the whole ourions affair; the oompany may have been registered to grab the very excellent title or something of the sort; but nevertheless it is a pity to see snch methods adopted, especially in the case of a banking compaD}."
his hank has no connection with the Bank of Commerce, which is held over for the presenf.

div.head: Bahr el Ghazal Mutiny ?
div.p: OFFICIAL DENIAL OF THE REPORT
WAR OFFICE V. NEWSPAPER

Considerable interest has been aroused by the reiteration of the War Office's dementi as to a mutiny having recently broken outam^ng the Sudanese troops in the Bahr el Ghazal province in view nf the categorical contradiction of the War Office's original dementi by the "Sadan Times" in its is3ae ot the 5th inst. That news­paper is published under the aeg's of the authorities at Khartoam, and the editor is so widply known and respected that no one will believe that he wonld wantonly contradict the War Office, especially in view of the extreme gravity of the news, unless be had the beat reasons for so doing and refused to allow such misrepresentations of faots to be officially set before the public.

Bet in yesterday's issue we were authorised to announce the ba-elessness of oar contempo­rary's statement, and it will be interesting to see whether the newspaper will stick to its gans and prove that its statements were true. The paragraph which has caused the trouble runs as follows :—
A mmour was current in Cairo last week that the Sudanese troops stationed at Bahr el-Ghazal had mutinied. The following statement, was, however, suppli­ed by the W»r Office:—
"A soldier of the 10th Sudanese, while in a state of inebriety, discharged his rifle several times. A ballet hit the foot of an Egyptian officer. The soldier was arrest-

The amonnt of inaccuracy in the infor­mation of the War Office is striking. This apolies to the "Explosion" case as well as the above case in which ten soldiers were arrested and conveyed to Khartoam to be oourt-martialled.
Yesterday we published the following dementi:—

We understand that there is no foundation for the report emanating from the "Sadan Times" that several soldiers had attaoked their officers at one of the Bahr el Ghazni stations. Apparently, the so called mutiny was oonfined to a soldier, who, under the inflneice of drink, or tropical irritability, or both, fired at an Egyptian officer, wounding him in the foot and afterwards committed snioide.

The matter will not end here, for it is incre­dible that our Khartoam oontemrorary will tacitly allow this second contradiction of the mutiny to pass unchallenged, if it had, as we presume it must have had, ample grounds for believing its statements to be troe at the time they were published. Moreover, it is strange that a newspaper published at Khartoum oould have been deceived in the matter, especially when it state* as a fact that ten soldiers bad been brought, to Khartoam for a court-martial. The blandest official optimism cannot explain away ten mutinous soldiers as a single drunken one. Nor oan the statements in the newspaper
glrzed over as due to a misprint or any sofh-like excuse, for they are reproduced in the Arabic portion of the same issue.

An explanation of the discrepancy between tfie official and newpaper versions of the mu­tiny will be awaited with considerable interest. Meanwhile both sides have our sympathy. We woald refase for a moment to believe any insinuations to the effect that the War Office hss been guilty of minimising a somewhat sedans affair in the interests of official expe­diency. Oa the o^hfr hand we oannot bring ourselves to believe that our excellent contem­porary oould have deliberately exaggerated the drunken freak of a single Sudanese soldier, and have gone out of its way to wilful'y oon- tradiot the War Office's statement on the snb­jeot. Offioial and g amour propre is
at stake, while the pablio is eagerly awaiting a solution of the riddle, especially since some other ouriona rumours have been brnited about as to the origin of the Khartoam explosion.

div.head: Paul Kochanski's Recital
div.p: Through the kind ffforts of the Comitd des F6tes Cairo ha* been favoured with a violin recital by M. Paul Kochanski which will long remain in the memory. We have still in our minds the excellent impression left by Signor Serato's playing, but there is no disloyalty in saying that M. Kochanski won the hearts of his audieDoe within the first five minutes of his appearance, and that eve*y item on the pro­gramme was received with extraordinary en­thusiasm. M. Koohanski is still a very young man, but his mastery of his instrument is wondeifal. The delicacy of his touoh and purity of tone are marvellous, but still more to be envied are his woiiderial depth of expres­sion and brilliancy of execution. The first item of the programme, "Allegro da Concerto en Rd majear" (Paganini) was a good introdnotion, bnt the Fantaisie from Faust by Wieniawski was a revelation, and gave him fall scope for his wonderful capabilities, and Chopin's Noc­turne with Sarasate's rendering provided him with yet another opportnnity of displaying his depth of feeling. Schumann's Reverie he played with mated instrument, but in Sarasate's ' Za pateado" he once more took the hearts of his audience by storm by his marvellous technique and power of expression. .Unfortunately time did not allow of our hearing the remainder of the programme, bat we are greatly indebted to the Comitd des Fdtes for having introduced this most talented artist to our midst, and hope we shall have many more opportunities oa listening to h'*m before the season draws to its close. Never have we seen the conorrt-room at the Savoy so filled as it was on Tuesday afternoon, and Dever have we *ean so apprecia­tive an audience in Cairo. The Comity des Fdres has our heartiest congratulations on the success of the last entertainment given by it.

div.head: Cyprus Mail Service
div.p: THE ISLAND ISOLATED
A PITIABLE STATE OF AFFAIRS
(From our Correspondent).
Nicosia, Maioh 5.

Cypras has been deprived for pome weeks of a regnlar mail service. Few here believed that such a thing wonld be allowed actually to come to pass, and even when the blow fell the in* habitants refused to believe that this isolation would be other than of very short duration. Consterration has now given way to a fueling of bewilderment and relnctant resignation. Officials feel that one of the few advantages attaching to an appointment in Cypras, namely, regular weekly communication with England, via Egypt, has been withdrawn, while merchants and others whose basiness is with foreign parts are suffering by reason of the uncertainty and delay in correspondence and means of transport which the cessation of the mai[ oontraot implies. The invariable testimony of impartial and competent persons who have from time to time visited the Island is that Cyprus possesses exceptional possibilities of development. There is an unvarying expression of opinion that with capital and proper means of transport this British dependency might again beoome what she formerly was, the graoarv and the gardea of the East, and within the latt few years a good trade with Egypt and European conntries has grown np. The isola­tion now imposed npon her can scaroely fail to oheok her powers of expansion and cause a most unfortunate shrinkage in her trade. It is earnestly to be hoped that a remedy for this pitiable state of things will soon be found.
Stook Breeding.

The annual Kourban Beyram Cattle Show was held on February 6 at Nicosia under the auspices of the Cyprus Committee for the ImDrovement of Native Animals. Owing to the difficulty of obtaining the necessary funds, it has not been possible to have this show for two years past. Its revival, therefore, is a matter of congratnlation, as mooh general interest is taken in it, and, if properly man­aged, good resalts should follow. This year the number of entries of all descriptions of animals (except horses unde* 13 hands 2 inohes) was large, and a good proportion of the animals brought up to be judged were well bred, exoel­lent animals. Particularly was this so in the case of the jaok and she donkeys. Remark­ably fine they were: large, staunoh animals, and evidently well oared for, and some diffi­culty was found in awarding the prizes. It is, however, a matter of regret that the committee is not more definite in its aims, a* d does not proceed on more systematic lines. For instance, the well-tried and eminently successful plan followed, probably, by all other societies of the kind, might well be adopted, viz: to keep stnd and herd books for wh:oh only snob animals wonld be eligible as might comply with the rnles and came up to the standard on which those books wonld be founded. As yet no official description appears to have been formulated for the general knowledge of breed ers, laying down the type to which a native horse, cow, donkey, or other animal should conform. If, then, shows are to be of real bene­fit, a type or standard to which to breed most be agreed upon. Breeders will then at least have a definite ideal before them, and judges will be able to k^ow what they are about. The small number of divisions in the olassea is due to want of funds, which prevents the committee from offering separate prizes for animals of varying ages and conditions. For instance, a class fur "caws," including heifers, is so comprehensive that to award a prize for the best "cow" without any reference whatever to her age, time of calving etc., is almost to defeat the end* the committee has in view, a faot which the committee itself wonld be the first to admit. Owners of stock who are in sympathy with the aims of the committee should, therefore, be ready to support its funds, and, while it wonld be unfortunate to do anything that might tend to reduce the number of exhibitors we cannot but think that with a view to increasing the prize fand, exhibitors shoald be willing to pay some email entry fee. Jadging by the large numbers that attended the show, and the excellent list of entries, it may be fairly concluded that the work of the committee has "caught on," and it is assnredly deserving of every encouragement. The mere holding of a show and the posses­sion of a few stnd animals shoald not, however, be the "be all and end all" of suoh a society, and we look forward to seeing some progress made in the direotion here indicated before next year's show.
Sir Wm Wllloooks.

Sir Wm. Willoooks, K.C.M.G., has been visiting the Island, and made a tour of the greater part nf it. After one month's stay he retarred to Egypt", but within a lew days came over for a flying visit, and ii now gone baok again to Cairo.
Religious Disturbance.

A few days ago Famagusta was the scene of a disturbance caused by the resentment of the Orthodox Greeks to theproseletyeing efforts of certain over zealous missioners in that town. Some excitement was aroused and damage to house property resulted, bat quiet was soon restored.

div.head: An Important Find
div.p: PATHETIC JEWISH RELIC
TEMPLE OF ONIAD DISCOVERED
Professor Flinders Petrie writes to us as follows : —

The work of the British S ihool of Archeology daring the winter has been in half-a-d* z«n sites along the east of the Delta ; the most interest­ing of the results at Tell el Yehudiyeh has been the identification of the ruin of the Temple of Onias. It is well known how the troubles of the Jews under Antiochus had driven many of them to settle in the east of the Delta. As a new rallying point one of the family of the High Priests had built a temple which served as a substitute for that of Jeru­salem. Josephus states that this temple was at an old Egyptian town, Leontopo'is, dedicated to Bohasris ; and we found here a thrine of a lion-headed goddess He states that the place was full of materials for building ; and there was here an enormous stone ditch, which supplied material even to the present day. He states that the permission was given to the Jews to build here by Pto'emy Philometor ; and we foand coins of that king on the temple site. He atate3 that the Jews built their temple here ; and we found a piece of an acconnt for bricks supplied by a man named Abram. He states that the building was 60 cubits high ; and we found that the mound with ruins on it mast originally have risen to this height. The general opinion therefore that Tell el Yehndiyeb near Shibin el Kanater was the place of Ouias is thus made certain by | oa* Ending the precise locality which agrees in every respect with the requirements.

This settlement of Onias was stroDgly forti­fied ; the town was about three or four aores in extent, and the temple site rose high above it on a platform abont 70 feet over the plain, An outer and inner coart lay in front of the temple, and the holy building was jast half the size of that of Solomon. It may be that Ezra's temple was of this size, hot it is not recorded. The architecture was Corinthian with Syrian features in the battlements. The walls were still standing twenty years ago, but the ravages of the sebakhin have now left only the foundations. Enough, however, oan be traced to restore all the outlines and some-of the details.

Daring the prepent weak I shall be at Tell el Yehudiyeh (two miles from 8hibin elKanater) and shall be glad to show the remains to any who may have an interest in this pathetio relic of the new Jerusalem in Egypt.

The British Sch iol has also worked out a Hykaos cemetery, and what appear* to be a Hy- kso* fortress here; and on other sites a gTanary town and a Urge cemetery in Goshen, and a new temple of Ramoses in the land of Saocoth. We hope that British residents and visitors will give their interest and sappoif to this Sohool, which is condaotiog the most extensive work by English excavators in tbie country.

div.head: Judicial Advisers Report
div.p: SUBSTANTIAL IMPROVEMENTS
NOTED.

The report of the Jadioial Adviser for 190 > contains the nsoal review of the matters coming within the province of the MinUtiy of Justice. In the fo lowing passage tin Adviser soma up the general situation of tho work of this Department at the present time :

It is submitted that very substantial im­provements have been effected in judioial matters in the course of the last few yean. The penal legislation has been extensive.y revised and very considerably improved, bo*h as to the substantive law and the prooedur', especially as regards appeals and the execu­tion of sentences. A considerable decentralisa­tion of justice, and far greater promptitude in the repression of crime, than heretofore prevailed, have been effected by the institu­tion of local Assize Courts, and cf Mark) z Tribunals. Children's Courts have been estab­lished in Cairo and Alexandria,—the only towns where, under present conditions, they were required—and have proved a deoidel success. The staff of judges and inspectors, both Native and Eugluh, has been materially increased, and resident English judges have been provided iu all the provincial centres except Keneh.

On the other hand, a great desl remains to be accomplished, before there can be any lull iu the aotivity of this Ministry. Further re- vi8:on of parts of the Penal Code and of the Code of Criminal Procedure are much required, and will be undertaken, as opportunity admits. Civil Procedure, too, is in urgent need of ac oeleration and simplification. The general composition of Courts calls for reconsideration, in the direction of reducing the number of judges required, both ;n firit instance and appeal. Notably the question of the feasibility of two jadga Courts for misdemeanour appeals, and that of materially extending the civil first instance competence of the Sammary Judges merit examination. The gradual extension of the penal jurisdiction of Markaz Tribunals must also be considered, in the near future; no should the possibility of conferring some civil jurisdiction on them be lost sight of.
In the way of procedure, some means most be sought for checking the present plethora of poiioe prosecutions in petty oases — notably as regards trompery charges of hurt or insalt.

As regards the Mehkemehs, even in default of greatly needed radical ancLorganio changes, something may be done to improve matters io the way of regulating the execution ofjudg meats, reorganising the present oonduob of work and distribution of Courts,and improving the calibre of the future personnel by the insti tution of ths proposed training College for Cadis and Mehkemeh oltrks. It may perhaps, also, prove possible to effect some modifications in the procedure in suits relating to Wakfs, which will give suitors greater guarantees of justice than they at present possess.

The above is only a brief and inojmpletc outlineof the more urgent improvements requir­ed in matters relating solely to native affairs. If there be inoladed a certain number of legii lative or administrative reforms affecting Europeans, constantly demanded by the public —such as a law of copyright, patents and trade-marks - and some of which are, it may be hoped, imminent—3uoh as the proposed reorganisation of the Registry Offices, under the direct oontroi of the Ministry of Jastice, it will be seen that the programme is qaite suffi oient to oooapy the Department for some time to come.
Thu Native Tribunal*.
On this subjeot the Adviser elsewhere re* marks :—

In general, I have little to add to what I have said for the last few years about the Native Tribunals. 1 believe that they are grad aally and steadily improving, all along the liue. No doubt decisions acd sentences ind'ea ting a deplorable lack of intelligence, and some­times of even ordinary oommon sense, are still by no means rare, and give rise, when they ocour, to angry comment on the part of Euro­peans. But the vast bulk of the judioial output of the Native Bench is very fairly datisfaotory, and increasingly so, year by year. A strong Native ju liciary and a sound system of jaetioe, in an Oriental country, cannot be brilt up in a day, and in such matters the twenty odd years of the Occupation am unt to little morj. Those who have watched the work of some of the Assiza Coarts this summer, composed, by reason of vacario \ arrangements, exclusively of Native Judges, have certainly no grounds for discouragement. Indeed, it has been a source of considerable satisfaction to them, and consider that it famishes a most hopefal augury f >r the fatare.

div.head: egypts tradeamerican imports
div.p: Mr. Morgan, of the American Diplomatic Agency and Consulate General at Cairo, in his recently published Consoler Report on Egypt­ian trade, makes the following remarks on American imports to Egypt : —

"1 was pleased to notice recently large arrivals of American-made furniture. The erotwhile cheap veneered artiole is rapidly being replaced by that made of solid wood, and it is my opinion that Amerioan manu- faotuiers oan more than hold their own here both for quality and price.

"In iron manufactures the United States continues on the down grade in imports to Egypt. The direotor of an establishment opened a short time ago for trade in exclusively Ame­rioan manufactures was compelled to abandon the business, and is now the head of a new oompany importing British machinery only. The American manufacturer in this instance lost more than his trade ; he lost experience and influence. He has secured for himself, however, a very powerful opposition to any further extension of his trade in Egypt.

"The petroleum market was lost some years ago for reasons very similar for the loss of the machinery market. Owing to the troubles in the south of Russia large consignments of American petroleum have been ordered for Egypt, but with the restarting of work in Russia the Batoum oil will again oome in, though it is agreed by all that American oil is Hr superior on all points. It is merely a question of«onforming to imperative local conditions whether our markets are to be ex­tended here. It is quite true that the ex­perience of the Amerioan exporter in Egypt has uot always been of the happiest, but from oareful inquiries made there oan be no doubt that great carelessness and want of judgment were exhibited in the choioe of agents. Pre­posterous olaims were made for shortages and breakages ; losses were inourred through bank ruptoies, but all this was years ago.'*

div.head: the deir el bahari shrine
div.p: The discovery by Messrs. Naville and Currelly of a shrine of the goddess Hathor at Deir el Bahari, containing a life-size figure of the cow-goddess still erect in her miniature temple, is of great value for the study of the success achieved by Egyptian sculptors, or mo­dellers, in delineating the animal figure when, as it would undoubtedly have been in this case, a considerable expense was inourred in proour- iug the very host work that the artists of the age could produce. But more important still it h anticipated will prove the reliefs with which the shrine walls are decorated for increasing our knowledge of the earlier forms of the Hathor
eult #

As the myth of Horns is recounted upon the late Ptolemaio temple of Edfou, so is the story of Hathor graven and painted upon the similar temple at Dendera. At Deir el Bahari we shall now have an earlier recension of the story. The cow deity Hathor has of oourse been found depioted with precisely the same attri­butes, and as in her newly-found image having the same disc, probably indicating the nootur nal sun in the nether world,surmounted by two feathers between her horns, and shown as just stepping forth from some papyrus reeds, gene­rally, howevei, also emerging from the moun­tain of the west. A drawing of her in this iconographies form may be found in M. Paul Pierrot's "Psnthdon Egyptian" (page 62). In at least one case, a copy of which is given in Lanzone's D.zionario di Mitologia Egizia (plate II),the dnois placed upon the head of a hawk- headel deiiylikely Horns) who is seated between the horns. Lana me oalls this form ol Hathor Aka, but in several representations she wears the Hathor capital symbol as a pectoral
ornament , ,

As Ha hor received the evening sun to be in her keeping until morn, so she gave birth to the rising sun and therefore is frequently shown nursing a child, Horus the suu god, or his earthly epreseutative the Pharaoh. By many texts the attributes of highest divinity are awarded her. For instance, at Ipsamboul an inscription say*, "Hathor is the Great One who has given birth to all the Gods," and at Dendera she is called the "Unique One," the word used being ua t in the feminine form.The rear of tb Deir el ILhari shrine abats on the western hi 1 and H»thor was add to dwell in tin mountain of the west and is shown in a sort of oave Of cleft of it receiving the setting sun.
Joseph Offobd.

div.head: mr. david garrick longworth- his happy life
div.p: The late Editor of the "Sphinx" write, in a recent issue of his Dew paper "The Globe Trotter" : A friend of mine writes to know if I am happy in this far away country (Nairobi) What am I to reply 1 Ideals differ in indivi­duals, my own are simple.

To camp under the open vault of heaven in a land unaltered since oreatioD, and in the glorious olimate of the East African highlands, free to pitch one's tent at will, and all the time surrounded by a wealth of wild animal life that surpasses all anticipation—such are mine. Here every day fresh forms, fresh sur­prises spring upon delighted eyes; wild orea- tures, many of transoendent grace, others of rarity or novelty, fill each passing day with interest and charm. Most of us have read Gordon Cumming and Baldwin, Cornwallis Harris, and the other pioneers in South Africa. I used to know them by heart, but feared I had lived a oentury too late—that such scenes existed no longer on earth. Bat in British East Africa they do still exist iu pristine glory. More than that, they are aooessible as they never were in South Afrioa at its zenith, for they oan be reaohed all the way by steam, both on land and sea, by first-olass liners and oorridor trains.
A maximum of pleasure with a minimum of disoomfort, is what I'm looking for, so I suppose I am happy, and don't know it, one seldom does realize what true happiness is until he is truly miserable.

div.head: um rus operations
div.p: The progress report for the half month ended January 81 is as follows:—"650 ft level north­east was advanoed 3 ft total distance 15 ft; vein averages 14 ins wide, assaying a trace. 650 ft level south-west was advanced 8 ft, total distance 25 ft; the vein, averaging 7 ins, was worth 15 dwts per ton. 550 ft main winze was deepened 11 ft, making the to til depth 89 ft ; vein 12 ins wide, assaying 7 dwts 9 grs per ton. 45 ' it level north east was extended 2 ft, making a total distance of 156 ft ; the vein at this point was 8 ins wide, giving an assay of over 6 ozs per tOD. 450 ft south west was extended 5 ft, total dLtanoe 165 ft, the vein averaging 18 ins wide and 1 oz 16 dwts 18 grs per ton in assay value. 350 ft level south-west was advanoed 14 it, making a total distance of 431 ft, the vein averaging 25 ins wide and 1 oz 1 dwt 8 grs per ton in value. Id a etope below this level the quartz averaged 14 ins wide, assaying 16 dwts 23 grs per ton. 245 ft north-east was advanced 14ft, total distance 324 ft; the vein, 18 ins wide, assaying 1 dwt 17 grs per ton. 245 ft raise at 16 ft north-east risen 7 ft, total height 22 ft ; the vein, 34 ins wide, was mixed with country rook, and gave an average assay of 6 dwts 23 grs per ton. 245 ft north east—No. 2 winze was deepened 15 ft, total depth 26 ft; the vein, 14 ins wide, assay­ed 5 dwts 4 grs per ton. 245 ft level south-west was advanoed 26 ft, making a total distanoe of 471ft; at 457 ft dyke No. 9 was encount­ered; this was passed through at 462 ft and holed into farther old stopes. A sample of quartz left on the soath-west of the dyke assayed 13 dwts 1 gr for 24 ins. In the stope below this level the quartz. 9 ins wide, assayed loz 19 dwts 4 grs per ton. Western shaft was deepened 8 ft. t< tal depth 308 ft; still in dyke. 27*) ft northeast was extended 17 ft to a total distance of 41 ft;the vein, averaging 9 ins, assayed 13 dwt* 22 grs per ton. 270 ft level south-west passed through dyke at 28 ft and was extended lift, making a total distanoe of 31 ft; the vein averaged 28 ins wide, assaying 11 dwts 2 grs per ton."

div.head: a classical arabic grammar
div.p: Mr. Reynold A. Nioholson has rendered a great service to all students of olassioal Arabio by editing the late Mr. Frederio du Pre Thornton's Elementary Arabio Grammar. When a writer of erudition, who is very quick at laDgoages, makes Arabio an almost life-long study, the fruit of his labours is sure to be of a high degree of exoelleuoe. This book, which is intended for students who oan read the language — for the transliteration is almost completely omitted, was previous! printed for private oiroulatioo only, and, as the editor tells us, was added to and corrected. Considering the width of its scope and the oonveuiemoe of its size, we have no hesitation in warmly recommending it to all those who wish to learn this beautiful but difficult tongue. Wright's grammar is one of the very best of classical Arabic, and this abridgement is oartainly sufficient for all practical purposep. Indeed, the student who masters this little book will possess a knowledge of Arabio gram mar more than is required by the resident or the ' ffioial in Egypt, un'e^s he wi^h^ to g still deeper iuto the subject when he w 1 ave to Htudv exha 'stive works montly in the - native Arabio garb.

This book is one of four, perhaps eve • fi e volumes, the rest being reading books intended to afford examples in illustration of the rul*-s of the grammar. The idea is certainly excellent, and the examples oited in this part, all of which are quotations from the Koran, are the best possible on account of the purity and excellence of the language in which the Sacred Book of the Mohamedans is written.

div.head: sport and play-lawn tennis-cairo tournament
div.p: The Cairo Lawn TeDnis Tournament came to a saooessfal conclusion on Saturday last, having lasted through the entire week. The entries were numerous and showed a decided advanoe on those of previous years.

Throughout the tournament a large and fashionable attendance watched the play with the keenest interest The presence in the tournament of Mr R. F. Doherty, the world- famed exponent of the game, and the holder with hia brother of the Doubles Champion­ship of the world, lent an additional inte­rest to the play : the games in which he fignrf d were followed with the closest attention, hi* magnificent strokes frequently evoking rounds of applause. ' As was only to be ex- peoted, a player of his calibre was very hea­vily handicapped, but not undaly so, as the result of the matches proved.
The arrangements, under the direction of Mr. Mackintosh, the Lawn Tennis Secretary, were excellent. The events were the follow­ing:
Gentlemen's Singles.
Gentlemen's Doubles, Open.
Gentlemen's Doubles, Handioap.
Mixed Doubles, Open.
Mixed Doubles, Handioap.
Ladies' Doubles, Handioap.

In the final of the Singles Major Stani- street, R A.M.C., whose play was often cha­racterised by most brilliant strokes, was too muoh for Mr. Moser, who himself played a very attractive game, the former running out a winner by 2 sets to love ^7-5, 6-3).
In the Gentlemen's Open Doubles, M*jor Stanistreet and Mr. Mackintosh had rather an easy win in the finals against Messrs. Hill and Patterson, winning by 2 sets to love, with the scores of 6*0, 6 3.

The Gentlemen's Doubles H'oap produced an extraordinary number of olosely-oontested matches (a tribute to the handicapping com­mittee), and was finally wonbyjlt, R. C. Moser and Mr. C. Barton, w^o^fMtedMessrs. Pollock and Slaten in the unal round. The winners played a pretty stylish game through­out, their volleying being often brilliant.

One of the most interesting matches was the semi final of the Mixed Doubles, Open, in which Mr. Mackintosh and Miss. H. Reokitt met Mr. Arohibald and the Hon. Mrs. Davey. After having won one set eaoh and reached 6 games all in the 3rd set on Friday evening, failing light put a stop to the play. It was thereupon agreed to replay the final set on Saturday, and it was a straggle well worth watching when this set came on, eaoh side in tarn taking the lead ; 5 all, 6 all, 7 all, and 8 all were called until finally Mr. Mao kintosh and Miss Reokitt won the set and match by 12 games to 10. Both ladies played exceedingly well, Miss Reokitt's brilliant returns being particularly admired.
It came as rather a surprise to those who had watched the play in this match to see the winners succumb in the final to Mr. Paton and Miss Cochran.

Without intending to disparage in the •lightest degree the play of the latter pair, it was exc eoted that the wieners of the match above described would have no difficulty in disposing of their opponents in the final, but on tbe contrary the latter were always playing a winning game, and it appeared as though the terrifying smashes of Mr. Paton hart a paralyzing effect on Miss Reokitt, completely putting her off her game and oausing her to attempt lobbing instead of playing the low and fast returns, at which game she exoels. Miss Corhr&n played an admirably steady game throughout, and she and her partner had the great advantage of coming fresh to the match, whilst her opponents were obvious­ly tired by their long struggle in the semi­final.

Id the Mixed Doubles H'oap Mr. T. J. Campbell and Miss de Bilinski (soratch) played a very sound game against Mr. R. F. Doherty and Miss de Villebois (owe 50) in the semi­final, and thoroughly deserved their victory : they followed up this suooess by defeating Mr. Green and Miss Loveless in the final, after a long struggle, in which Mr. Campbell's fine foroing game and his partner's pluok and steadiness were the oocasion of muoh well- reserved applause

In the Ladies Doubles H'oap, the winners, Mias Versoboyle and Miss Morgan were pr«t- bably treated rather generously by the bandi oapper, their opponents in the final, Miss Davey and Miss Trevithick,finding the odds of ' receive 30" too muoh for them, though they made a plucky fight, and only lost by 6 games to 8 in the third and final set.
At the conclusion of the tournament the prizes, which were very handsome, were dis­tributed to the winners by the Countess of Cromer.

div.head: football- tantah school v. nondescripts
div.p: A Tantah correspondent writes :—Although football has only been introduced into this country in reoent years, the interest the Tantah inhabitants take in a football match is more than usual. Yesterday afternoon the Tantah Government School playground pre­sented a remarkable scene, one that has never been seen here before. Indeed the reoent appointment of Ahmed Eff. Sadik as a teacher of English and as drill instrui for to this sohool has added muoh to its fame and organisation. At 2.15 p.m. a party of scholars, olad iu white trousers and black jerseys, made their appear •uoe on the playground amidst the cheers of the orowds of spectators. The boys went through some exercises in drill and gymnastics in a manner that was greatly admired by the spectators, whose faces beamed with joy at witnessing the smartuesss of the young ohtm- pions.

At 8.80 p.m. the native and "nondescript" (quasi-English) teams appeared on the ground, and though there was some disparity in age between the members of the two teams, the nati­ves defended their goal gallantly. However they were able to soore only one goal to their opponents' four. Mi Brookwy, drill inspector, noted as referee. The matoh came to an end by 5.80 p.m., when three oheers were given and tea was served.

div.head: Chronoque Judiciare
div.p: Le Procès des Princes.
Avant-hier matin a été appelé à l'andience de la deuxième Chambre Civile da triboDal mixte du Caire le procès des prinoes contre la Daïra Sanieh.
L'affaire a été renvoyée ponr être plaidée an 27 avril prochain.

Ce renvoi h one date anssi éloignée est motivé par l'impossibilité où se trouve Maître Villa, avocat italien et dépnté, qui doit rem­placer dans cette affaire Me Poincaré, de s'absenter avant cette époque, retenu qu'il est jusque lh par les travaux parlementaires
Mtre Pietri a insisté d'une façon énergique ponr que cette affaire soit plaidée le 27 avril sans antre renvoi.
Mtre Manusardi a pris la parole et a promis de plaider lui-même si, à oette date Mtre Villa, pour ub6 raison impossible à prévoir, était etnpêohé à nouveau.

div.head: Delegation Municipale
div.p: {Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Munioipale s'est réunie le 13 mars 1906 à 4 b. p m. sous la présidence de M. Ambroise A. Ralli.
Présents M.M. R Benaohi, L. Esooffier, Baron A. de Menasce, Mansonr Bey Yonssef, 0. Rothaoker, Dr. Sohiess Pacha, G. Zervu- daohi, membres, W. P. Chataway, adminis­trateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.

La Délégation prend note d'une lettre de l'administration des Prisons acceptant de par­ticiper à oonourrenoe de L.E. 360 aux irais de oonstruotion d'égout pour l'écoulement des eaux de la prison de Hadra.

Elle décide de renvoyer à l'examen du Contentieux, au point de vue de certaines questions de prinoipe qu'elle soulève, une demande de M. Agathon Bey tendant à l'in­troduction à Alexandrie de viande oongelé9.
La Délégation soumettra à la Commission les communications ministérielles qu'elle a reçues pour la composition de la nouvelle Commission Munioipale.
Elle adjuge àM, D. Mosoatelli, au prix de LE. 197 1/2 les travaux de oonstruotion d'une toiture pour l'atelier des écuries de Chatby.

La Délégation accepte avec plaisir une pro­proposition du service d'arpentage tendant à exécuter des plans partiels d'Alexandrie et invite le service teohnique h se mettre h la ' disposition de la dite administration pour tous les renseignements ou toutes les indications qui lui seraient utiles pour la confection du travail dont B'agit.

Elle émet un avis favorable à des demandes de la 8ociété des Tramways et de Mr. Tivoli relatives à l'organisation de servioes d'omnibns J automobiles, l'autorisation devant être aooordée ; par le Qouvernorat aux mêmes conditions que pour les exploitations similaires déjà concé-
La Délégation s'ocoupe de l'installation de nouveaux postes de pompiers à Ramleh et à l'Ibrahimieh et oharge les servioes de reoher- ! oher les meilleurs emplacements pour les ins- tallations.
Elle décide la construction de chalets de nécessité dans la rue Ebn Touloun, près du oimetière de la colonne Pompée.
Une séanoe de la Commission Munioipale tara lieu le 21 Mars 1906.
La séanoe est levée à 6 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN De la Bourse
div.p: (Aujourtlmi à midi et demie)

Ce matin le marché a ouvert en pleine iffervesœnce pour les Nungovioh qui ont atteint £ 18. On dit que cette société aurait rsndu le Continental pour la somme de 495000 ivres à la condition qu'il serait remplaoé par in établissement de genre différent. S'il faut n oroire le même bruit, les Estâtes seraient ss acheteurs, mais cette nouvelle mérite con- relation.

Une demande considérable se produit en 'rbaine. L'opinion générale est qae la hausse ur cette valeur sera extrêmement rapide, (ans que'qnes jours doit avoir lieu l'assemblée ui prononoera sur la prochaine émission d'ao- ions.

A l'Assemblée extraordinaire de la Land Jlotment, tenue avant hier au Caire, les ao- onnaires ont autorisé le conseil d'administra- on à étendre les opérations de la société aux ays limitrophes à l'Egypte. M. W. Willoooks it déjà reparti pour Chypre pour s'y occuper e la Banque Agricole dont la société a obtenu i privilège, ainsi que de diverses concessions t terrains. Le titre est le plus en plus de Ohdé.'
On s'attend à une reprise prochaine et sensi le sur l'Agrioole, la National, et la Delta ight, depuis longtemps délaissées à des prix as.
De nombreux échanges ont eu lieu en Na- onal Bank, Estâtes, Urbaine, Cassa di Soonto, taira, et Investment.
La National s'avanoe à 27 15/16, la Béhéra 39, la Daira à 18 1/8, l'Inve-tment à 1 6/16 t la Ramleh Railway à 6 16/16 aoheteurs.
En revanche, l'Oasis fléohit à 1 5/16 vendeurs b les Cotton Mills à 7/9.
Le mouvement sur le Delta Light reprend internent, mais sûrement. On clôture aujour- hui à 12 7/16 acheteurs.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRale
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA

Les débuts de M. Le Bargy ont eu lieu hier soir devant une salle comble. On donnait le "Marquis de Priola,'' de Lavedan. La pièoe a permis à l'admirable artiste, sinon de nous don­ner toute la mesure de sou talent, du moins de mettre en relief quelques-unes de ses pré­cieuses qualités. M. Le Bargy a, en effet, in­carné d'une façon remarquable le héros de Lavedan, oe séduoteur impeooable et libertin oynique.

L'ensemble de la troupe est bon. Noos mentionnerons en première ligne Mme Dauss- mor d dont on a admiré le talent subtil et dél ioat. Mme Bernon, qui remplissait le rôle de Mme Lechêne, femme divorcée du Marquis de Priola, s'est aussi distinguée. Dans une autre pièce, nous pourrons appréoier les autres artistes.
Ce soir, "Le Demi-Monde".

div.p: Nous avons le regret d'annoncer la mort de Mademoiselle Irene Bartolo, survenue cette nuit à l'Ibrahimieh.
Les funérailles auront lieu cette après-midi, à 5 h. 1/2, au oimetière oatholique.

div.head: army and navy
div.p: , (Prom our Correspondknnt).
London, March 3.

Captain F. G. Poole, D.9.O., East Yorkshire Regiment, now serving with the Egyptian Army, and who has jast been promoted to bis captaincy in the gallant •'Snappers," has had a varied oareer. A Kent man by birth, his fad has been foreign travel and he has seen a lot of the world. He was gazetted to the E*st York*, from Sandhurst, in 1892. and from 1896 to 1899 he was employed in the British Central Africa Protectorate, and shared in the expeditions against Chilwa and Mpezeni (medal with clasp), saw farther service in the troubles in Northern Rhodesia, and was in China during the Boxer troubles. Dnrirg that very trying period he was in the besieged Legations of Peking and commanded the volanteers of all nationalities which helped to hold the place. He was woanded daring the defence of the Legations, and afterwards was a Staff officer of the China Field Foroe, and combined the duties ot Transport officer with that of interpreter, he being a very ab'e Chinese scholar (mentioned in despatches, D.8.0, medal with clasp). Captain Poole, who for the past three years hes bjen attached to the Khe live's army, has written a bit on foreign travel, and he has the honour of being a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society.
Captain P. M. Dove, Sherwood Foresters, h%s been formally seconded for service with the Egyptian A my.

The Royal Berkshire Regiment has lost the services of Lientenant A. W. Norris, attached to the 1st Battalion at Dublin, at d latterly employed with the Gold Coast Raiment of the West African Frontier Force. Mr. Norris has resigned his commission after less than six years' service.

The order for the Dilwara to leave Sonthampton with reinforcing drafts for regiments in Sonth Africa has been rescinded and the Assaye, arriving h me from India on Maroh 8 with hore and field batteries, will take out the Soath African drafts, leaving Soothampton on March t6.
The new cruiser Dake of Edinbu^gh-will be commissioned at D*vouport on March 13 to relieve the cruiser Ees^x in the Seoond Cruiser Squadron. The E^ex will pay off at Devon- porton Maroh 19.

The "Standard" says that since the Atlantio Fleet and Second Cruiser Squadron have been based at Gibraltar the importance of tin arsenal fias vastly increased. The dock yard work has gone up to such an extent that § 000 Spaniards are now employed in tbs yard. Bat the removal of the ships from British banes has caused a Urge reduction of staff at the Inme ports, and over 5,000 of the men were discharge 1 from Portsmouth, Devonport, Chatham, and Pern broke last year, wifh the resait that there has been much distress in the dockyard towns this winter. In many quarters there is a strong feeling that unemployed British dockyard men should be sent to Gibraltar, and the Spaniards discharged—particularly as the Spanish work­men are apt to learn things which ought to remain secret to Great Britain, and as many disptiarge4 Englishmen have been driven to America and Germany, oarrying those secretB with them.

Dr. Dillon writes in the ' ContempojAry" on the policy of the Kaiser as it has been dis played at Algeciras. His Majesty's policy. Dr. Dillon writes, is a modification, as well as a sharpening, of that of Bismarck.

The E npe^or's first Chancellor, despite the wonderfal ease of conscience with which he was wont to adopt effective measures to attain his ends, drew a line where ^i'h^m II draws none. Bismarck, for example, never excused, still less defended, the Turks when they took to killing Christians en masse. On the other hand, he did materially assist the Bulgarians in their straggle for freedom. Again, he never made any allianoe, real or formal, with ths Saltan, for whom h» felt and expressed scant respect. The Kaiser, on ^the contrary, has done that, and mnch more than that He now has two M -hamedan clients : the Saltan of Turkey and the Sultan of kforopco, who both look to him to per­petuate Liam in a world in which it is an anachronism. He is thought of in the Orient as a polygamist in the sphere of ideas, a man who can love and espouse several causes even when they seem to conflict one with the other. Bat the Kaiser is a shrewd politician withal. In his dealings with countries not yet opened up he is wisely resolved to re­frain from taking territory, to abstain from offering advice contenting himself with com­mercial and industrial concessions. They form, bo to say, the o-e thing needful; everything else will be anperadded to the ration that has these.
The moral for Eiglan-l, looking at what has occurred with regard to Frjnce, is, "Foie warned, forearmed."

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries ET BOUTIGNY.
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 10 mars.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a hanssé hier de 1/8 à 90 7/8 et TUnifiée de 1/1 à 105 1/2. La National Bank et l'Agricole sont restées invariées à 27 5/8 et 10 1/*. LaDsïra Sanieh a baissé de 1/8 à 17 3/4.
A Paris, l'aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien
est renseignée en reprise de 2 francs à 7 94 et
la Banque d'Athènes de 1 franc à 145.
Notre marohé des valenrs a été, ce matin encore, très aotif et très ferme sur plusieurs valeurs.

La National Bank, toujonrs inert9, est restée à ses prix d'hier. Plus animée, l'Agri oole s'est insorite à 10 1,16 l'action ancienne, et 9 5/8 la nouvelle. La Cassa di Soonto a haussé de 210 à 216. L'aotion Crédit Foncier a progressé à 791 et l'obligation à lots 1836 à 342.
L'aotion Immobilière a avancé à 392 ; la part de fondateur à f59. La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil est montée à 7 1/2.
La part de fondateur Enterprise and Deve­lopment est revenue à 17 1/2. La part de fondateur Land Allotment a atteint 177 pour olôturer à 168.

L'aotion Société d'Entreprise3 Immobilières et Travaux s'est maintenue à 4 1/2 ; on ne tardera pas certainement à voir des oours plus élevés. La part de fondateur a atteint jusqu'à L. E. 19 1/2 pour olôturer à 18. On sait qu'il avait été déoidé, dès la constitution de la Société, de subdiviser ohaque part de fonda­teur en 25 couperas. Les nouveaux titres seront mis en oiroulation dans deux mois.

L'aotion Brasserie des Pyramides est montée à 133 ; la part de dividende à 79. Un mouve ment de hausse sérieux semble se dessiner sur oe titre ; on affirme que la Société est en train de conolnre la vente de ses terrains à des prix extrêmement avantageux.
Les Omnibus du Caire sont à 27 aohetenra.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, il y a eu des transactions très importantes sur les National, qui ont atteint 4 5/8. Le public commence à s'intéresser à oe titre, dont la hausse parait devoir s'aooentuer rapidement. Les acheteurs sont sérieux

Parmi les petites valeurs, fort mo ivement de hausse—que nous avions prévu depuis longtemps—sur les Cotton Mills ; on a clô­turé à 8 sb. 6. Les Oasis ont également avancé à 1 5/8. Les Sait and Soda restent à 24 sh. 6. Les Estâtes ont fait 2 3/16 ; la part de fondateur a enoore gagné £ 1 1/2 à 12 5/8. Les Egyptian Constructions sont revenues à 1 11/16.

Il y a lieu de s'attendre Bur les Agricoles du Nil à un mouvement de hausse, qui serait d'ailleurs justifié par les brillantes opérations faites par la Société. Une seule d'entre elles a, paralt-il, donné un bénéfice de 11,000 livres.
Il ne faut pas, d'antre part, perdre de vue le revenu rapporté par le beau domaine acquis Tan passé. Bien que oonsigné au milieu de l'année, l'exploitation agrioole de oes terrains
donne déjà un profit "net" de 4 à 5 pour cent.
On assure que l'émission publique de la Gairo Heliopolis Metropolitan Eleotrio Rail- way Co. (Oasis du désert de l'Abbassieh), aurait lieu dans le coarant du mois pTochaiD.
La oapital social, s'élevant à 15,<"03,000 de franos, est représenté par 60,000 aotions de 210 francs chacune, entièrement souscrites par les fondateurs.
La proportion qui serait offerte au public serait de 20 %, soit 12,000 aotions.
La souscription serait ouverte simultané­ment an Caire, à Bruxelles et à Paris.

Diverses rumeurs sont en oiroulation au sujet de la hausse qui vient de se produire sur les aotions de la Western Egypt Corporation (Oasis). Le bruit a couru hier en Bourse, au Caire et à Alexandrie, qu'une mine de houille avait été découverte sur les lieux.

Ce qui est certain, o'est que la Sooiété a organisé une expédition chargée d'explorer l'oasis Maluk, qui passe pour être très intéres­sante au point de vue minéralogique. Cette expédition se mettra en route dans un dizaine de jours.
